75001 Paris
+33 (0)1 40 28 13 11
https://www.cavesdulouvre.com

content.title: The most beautiful luxury shops in Paris

introduction.small: For those who go on shopping sprees or simply like to go window-shopping, luxury and haute couture will meet all your expectations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The most beautiful luxury shops in Paris

paragraphs.text:
Luxury boutiques have taken over various neighbourhoods of the French capital. Within the famous golden triangle, Avenue Montaigne welcomes designer houses among the most prestigious in the world (Chanel, Dior, Nina Ricci…). Several luxury brands have taken hold two steps away, on the Avenue des Champs-Élysées, like Louis Vuitton and perfumer Guerlain. The shops are usually huge, sometimes over several floors, and offer a large selection of products.
For a quieter shopping break, the fancy Place Vendôme is specialised in watchmaking and goldsmithery. There, you will have the opportunity to gaze at dreamlike watches and jewels, Cartier's and Van Cleef & Arpels' for instance.
Finally, go out of your way to the Saint-Lazare neighbourhood (with the Printemps and Galeries Lafayette department stores) where all of French luxury has been gathered. During Christmas season, visitors from around the world rub shoulders to have a look at the shop windows. Designed by the best creators, they display animated fantasy worlds.

content.title: Les Commères, the first Parisian pastry bar

introduction.small: While wandering through the charming streets of Paris' 9th arrondissement, you will not be able to resist the call of sweet treats offered by Les Commères.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Commères, the first Parisian pastry bar

paragraphs.text:
South of the Place Pigalle, in the trendy new neighbourhood known as “So-Pi” (for South Pigalle), and a stone's throw from the Butte Montmartre and the Sacré-Cœur, Les Commères offers homemade pastries to be enjoyed with delicious fruit cocktails. High-flying sweet bites like the passion fruit-pineapple pie, the chocolate pudding or the pistachio puff and wild strawberry Saint Honoré will be best relished in this enchanting setting. As for the cocktails, the Fifi and Rosy remain key drinks, sweet and subtly decorated. You will also find a small selection of savoury tapas to be had with a glass of white, rosé or red wine - in moderation, of course.
This next generation bar adorned with plant walls and mosaic flooring, offers brass-covered cutlery and wooden furniture. Lighting remains subtle and slightly subdued, creating a warm and relaxing atmosphere where you can meet with friends or family at any time of the day… or night!

Les Commères
31 Rue Victor Massé
75009 Paris

+33 (0)6 50 94 38 30

https://www.lescommeres-paris.com/

Pastries: from 6 EUR

content.title: Le Dôme, Montparnasse's oldest institution

introduction.small: One of the major fish restaurants in Paris, Le Dôme gets an overhaul thanks to its new Japanese chef, while retaining its indomitable spirit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Dôme, Montparnasse's oldest institution

paragraphs.text:
Simone de Beauvoir, Jean-Paul Sartre, Picasso, Lenin and Trotsky… In their time, all these famous figures were regulars of the Dôme, founded in Montparnasse in 1898. Today, the institution has retained its Art Deco feel, just like the other brasseries designed by Slavik: orange bench seats, large wooden counter, colourful stained-glass windows… The gold-leaf covered ceiling, contemporary chandeliers and winter garden are all recently added touches to breathe new life into the restaurant, whilst retaining its original soul.
Highly talented Japanese chef Yoshihiko Miura, one of the few chefs to hold a licence in “fugu” – the poisonous blowfish that is sublime in sashimi, as long as you are an expert in preparing it – has already put his personal stamp on the dishes. The modernised menu changes every day, subject to product availability, although the fish stew and sole meunière remain hallmarks. The eclectic wine list will satisfy even the most demanding customers. To end on a sweet touch, the irreplaceable Napoleon millefeuille will delight those with a sweet tooth. Uncommon sense of good service rounds up the charm of an unforgettable moment.

Le Dôme
108 boulevard du Montparnasse
75014 Paris

+33 (0)1 43 35 25 81

https://www.restaurant-ledome.com/

Menu: from 73 EUR, lunch menu from 48 EUR

content.title: Dai Dai, the Venezian-style aperitivo in Oberkampf

introduction.small: From cold cuts to pizze and antipasti, take your pick at Dai Dai, the trendy new Italian spot in the 11th arrondissement.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dai Dai, the Venezian-style aperitivo in Oberkampf

paragraphs.text:
Italian cuisine has found a new advocate amid the famous and lively rue Oberkampf, and not just any: Dai Dai (come on, come on in English) reinvents the appetizer. In small or large parties, food lovers will take a seat within chic and refined decoration to share ciccheti, the Venetian answer to tapas. Imagine variations on bruschetta that can be filled at your will, adding colourful vegetables, cheese and hams. To make this moment truly unforgettable, indulge in a typical pizza, such as the Tartufo with its black truffle cream, or the Rotolino, rolled into a filoncino and ready to be shared. Care for something more original? Then give the Dark Vadhor a try and explore the dark side of the pizza! With its squid ink base, it will definitely take you by surprise. At Dai Dai's, the border lines between Italy and France have never been that thin!

Dai Dai
25 rue Oberkampf
75011 Paris

https://dai-dai.fr

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: Beaupassage, the rebirth of Parisian passages

introduction.small: In the heart of Beaupassage, hybrid place of life of the 7th arrondissement, visitors wander through an open-air mixture of restaurants and art galleries, all in a zen environment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beaupassage, the rebirth of Parisian passages

paragraphs.text:
Totally new and yet already considered one of the most beautiful passages of the French capital, it connects three mythical streets - boulevard Raspail, rue du Bac and rue de Grenelle - just a stone's throw from the Bon Marché department store. Its elegant architecture of typically Parisian style makes the premises a must-go-to for lazing around. In open-air green areas (counting up to 60 different tree varieties), passersby roam through art installations scattered all around - here by Fabrice Hyber, there by Eva Jospin or Stefan Rinck.
Beaupassage is also the most gastronomic street in France, home to some of the greatest chefs of our time, most of them boasting several Michelin stars: Yannick Alléno (3 stars) and his Allénothèque restaurant-wine cellar, Thierry Marx and his Thierry Marx Bakery, Anne-Sophie Pic and her Daily Pic cantina, and even pastry chef Pierre Hermé and his Café Pierre Hermé. Everything is made for you to enjoy a sense of serenity during this cultural and gourmet break.

content.title: A world view at Hugo & Co

introduction.small: Refined and satisfying, the food at Hugo & Co takes you to all five continents in a friendly atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A world view at Hugo & Co

paragraphs.text:
With his characteristic passion and energy, Michelin-starred chef Tomy Gousset has created a stylish and laid-back atmosphere for his new establishment, centred around a gigantic open-plan kitchen. The concept is based on sharing, the idea being to choose several dishes to put on the table and to try them all.
Plates are always displayed with the utmost care: from Cambodian bao buns and oxtails to a tabbouleh revisited with fried tofu and avocado, the chef has a talent for exalting each dish.
Hugo & Co looks halfway between a typically chic Parisian bistro and a trendy New York bar. The décor features small wooden crates stacked to the ceiling and filled with plants to form a refreshing wall of greenery, lit with multicoloured neon lights. On sunny days you can eat outside on the terrace, which can accommodate a dozen guests. Venture out with friends or family, you will not regret it!

Hugo & Co
48 rue Monge
75005 Paris

+33 (0)9 53 92 62 77

https://www.tomygousset.com/hugo-and-co/

Menu: around 36 EUR

content.title: Boteco Lapa, an authentic Brazilian bar in the heart of Paris

introduction.small: At Boteco Lapa, tapas, drinks and even the atmosphere have a deceptive air of Copacabana. South America has never felt this close!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Boteco Lapa, an authentic Brazilian bar in the heart of Paris

paragraphs.text:
Smooth Bossa Nova notes already set the tone: at Boteco Lapa, the ambiance is warm and caipirinhas reign supreme. On the stone walls and overlooking the bench seats showcasing tropical patterns, the Mona Lisa lovingly hugs Pelé, the global 1960s football icon and national hero, as a nod to the spirit of this place where Brazil meets France. The establishment is run by two friends, one French and the other Brazilian, who wanted to recreate the ambiance of a real boteco - bar in Portguese They have succeeded! With decoration evoking the Amazon rainforest and a refined menu harking back to Ipanema, you will be able to share typical tapas like picanha beef, black beans and sesame hummus, tapioca pudding dadinho (tapioca with grilled cheese, Serrano ham and sweet and sour sauce), as well as the signature ceviche. Pair this South American culinary adventure with a Tonka bean beer, brewed on site, or one of the many variations on the caipirinha, for example the caipi-maté (rum, ice maté, lemon and thyme syrup), all in moderation. You can even learn how to make yours during one of the cocktail lessons, every first Saturday of the month. Cheers! Or as you say in Brazil, Tim-Tim!

Boteco Lapa
48 rue de l'Échiquier
75010 Paris

https://www.boteco.paris/boteco-lapa

Menu: tapas from 9 EUR

content.title: Delve into art at the Atelier des Lumières

introduction.small: Art meets technology at the Atelier des Lumières in the 11th arrondissement of Paris, where visitors move through gigantic paintings in perpetual motion.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Delve into art at the Atelier des Lumières

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of the Atelier des Lumières (Lights Workshop) is a new-generation museum. Within a former 19th-century foundry that was entirely renovated, this centre for digital art puts key artistic figures in the spotlight. Over 3,300 sqm, art pieces come alive, from floor to ceiling and in very high resolution, screened on concrete surfaces that are sometimes ten metres high.
For total immersion, a soundtrack played over dozens of steerable speakers guides visitors and adds unprecedented emotional impact to the overall experience. Each exhibition presents various artists and explores different themes, retro-lit and animated. Children are free to run around, sit down, touch the walls and ask endless questions. There, technology is only a means to make art accessible and more playful for younger (or less so) generations. A 2.0 educational and innovative museum.

Atelier des Lumières
38, rue Saint-Maur
75011 Paris

+33 (0)1 80 98 46 00

https://www.atelier-lumieres.com/en/home

content.title: Paris-Paris, the trendy brasserie of the 10th arrondissement

introduction.small: After the success of their three Parisian addresses devoted to the art of hamburgers, the PNY team has decided to give pride of place to the classics of French bistro cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Paris-Paris, the trendy brasserie of the 10th arrondissement

paragraphs.text:
For a few years now, the neighbourhood has been a meeting point for young Parisian hipsters. On Rue du Faubourg-Saint-Denis between two packed terraces, Paris-Paris stands proud in a competitive atmosphere with other trendy addresses whose reputation is firmly established. True there is nothing to be ashamed of: from the street, the restaurant shines brightly. Light globes hanging from the ceiling along an immense golden rack, oak wood tables and counter catch the eye while contrasting with stone walls. This very carefully conceived design is the work of the Cut Architectures studio.

Once seated, try the hooked saucisson or the cucumbers in cream for starters. For the main, choose between steak and fries with a “Café de Paris” sauce, pasta shell mac & cheese to rejuvenate childhood memories or a free-range chicken, which are just as good. As for brunch aficionados, rendez-vous is taken on the weekend for a hot chocolate, freshly pressed juice, organic eggs, soldiers and homemade jam. Your tastebuds will thank you for the attention!

Paris-Paris
74, rue du Faubourg-Saint-Denis
75010 Paris

+33 (0)9 81 86 68 08

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: Marcello, a pleasant encounter between Turin and Brooklyn

introduction.small: Welcome to Marcello, where dishes pass by at the pace of your gourmet desires!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marcello, a pleasant encounter between Turin and Brooklyn

paragraphs.text:
In Saint-Germain-des-Prés, the favourite haunt of artists, Duke Ellington fired up crowds and Samuel Beckett debuted his play Waiting for Godot at the Petit Théâtre de Babylone. Today, 100m from the Église Saint-Sulpic, a Torino-style café elegantly meets a New York-style bar, while onlookers' prying eyes gaze dreamily from Mabillon street. Surprising and innovative, the Marcello café-restaurant is becoming a GHQ for foodies, dreamers and night owls alike. The sun's rays dance on the cobbled terrace and round tables which, at nightfall, are still covered with good food.
At sunrise, an infusion of fresh fruit and Italian croissants awaken you to the sweetness of a Parisian morning. As the hours go by, gourmets nibble between meetings on the fried smelt and "oysters of the poor" and enjoy a few arancini with black truffle chips at the end of the day. Sip on your Spritz Nuage (spritz with homemade orgeat), the time it takes for your avocado and mozzarella focaccia or ricotta and aubergine gnocchi to be served. In the evening, enjoy a red fruit gratin with a scoop of marsala for a moment of freshness.

Marcello
8 rue Mabillon
75006 Paris

+33 (0)1 43 26 52 26

https://www.marcello-paris.com/en/

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: Shiver as you listen to the legends of cursed Paris

introduction.small: Follow an unconventional guide who will lead you in discovering legends of the capital: you will never see Paris the same way again.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shiver as you listen to the legends of cursed Paris

paragraphs.text:
Paris has lived through centuries, experienced the throes of history and was treaded upon by millions. Today, Guillaume Bertrand shares his deepest secrets. It's at nightfall, on the forecourt of the Notre-Dame de Paris Cathedral that this young history buff, passionate about the past of civilisations, will meet you for a captivating saga.
Set off on a two-and-a-half-hour tour through the cobbled streets of the heart of the capital, when the City of Lights darkens to make way for legends and myths. First stop: the devil's door of Notre-Dame. Guillaume will then guide you to various history-filled places: Chatelet's former prison, Palais de Justice and the Medici column. An exhilarating journey full of thrills that you will never forget! Remember to book in advance, these nocturnal visits are rather popular among the curious.

Paris maudit
Sous Les Pavés
Paris centre
Start: Île de la Cité / End: Les Halles

+33 (0)7 64 16 87 22

content.title: Golden Ticket for Chapon et la Chocolaterie

introduction.small: Notice to all the little Charlie Buckets at heart: Patrice Chapon keeps opening chocolate addresses in the heart of Paris. On your marks, get set, devour!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Golden Ticket for Chapon et la Chocolaterie

paragraphs.text:
If Roald Dahl, author of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, was still writing his peculiar poetry, perhaps he would allow himself a visit to Patrice Chapon's chocolaterie. One of the rare chocolate-makers who roast their cocoa, master chocolate maker Chapon has been crafting his naughty gourmet creations since 1986. Dive into one of this peerless artisan's unique Parisian boutiques – there are three others around the capital, in Chelles, Saint-Mandé and Meaux - with their delightful aromas and captivating treats.

It was while exploring the plantations and regions of Madagascar, Peru and Venezuela that the chocolatier decided to reveal the different production stages of his brown gold in his shops in the capital: on the shelves, chocolate bars, ganache and pralines crumble and drip with delicious mischievousness. His latest product, the Chocolate Mousse Bar, invites afficionados to choose between chocolates from several different countries: Ecuador, Madagascar, Venezuela or “Equagha” (combination of Peru and Venezuela) and presents the most recent addition, mousse from Peru… A moment of pure pleasure for the tastebuds!

content.title: Discovery of the Orient at the Arab World Institute

introduction.small: The Arab World Institute (AWI) presents the richness and splendour of Arab cultures and civilisations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discovery of the Orient at the Arab World Institute

paragraphs.text:
Moments from the Jardin Tino Rossi, home to the Musée de la Sculpture en Plein Air (Outdoor Sculpture Museum), where you will find an exhibition of works from the second half of the 20th century, stands an astonishing building, to say the least, with mashrabiya-covered facades. Welcome to the Arab World Institute, a unique place that aims to establish and maintain close ties between Eastern and Western cultures.

The four floors of the Institute, which was inaugurated in 1987, invite you to discover all the various aspects of Arab cultures: arts, language and literature, science, religion, society… With its themed layout, the museum explores the long history of these thousands of years-old civilisations. Wander into a reconstructed Eastern city, before discovering the many examples of Arab-Muslim beauty. This diverse collection, the many temporary exhibitions and links to other museums will immerse you in a unique and colourful culture. An enriching time that will take you on a journey.

Institut du monde arabe
1 rue des Fossés Saint-Bernard
Place Mohammed V
75005 Paris

+ 33 (0)1 40 51 38 38

www.imarabe.org/en

content.title: Le Nolinski, a very Parisian boutique hotel

introduction.small: In the heart of the capital, the Nolinski Paris plays on French chic and proves to be the perfect point of departure to discover the City of Light.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Nolinski, a very Parisian boutique hotel

paragraphs.text:
The Nolinski Paris, just a few steps from the Comédie-Française and the Jardin du Palais-Royal, cultivates the art of detail. During your travels, you may have noticed that some hotels rely on an olfactory signature, a unique touch that forever anchors an establishment in the memory of its guests. The Nolinski is one of those places.

Having barely set foot in the lobby, you can immediately enjoy its subdued atmosphere, with scents of spices and musk. The architect Jean-Louis Deniot shows the elegance of Paris with shades of blue and emerald-green in the lobby and the salons. In the 45 rooms and suites spread over six floors, you discover the same elegance: grey polished concrete enhanced by shades of green, raspberry, beige and blue, not to mention the noble materials and mouldings, like true Haussmann apartments.

As for food, Philip Chronopoulos, chef of Nolinski Le Restaurant, serves up sunny, contemporary cuisine with hints of the Mediterranean, for example little veal chaussons, roasted cauliflower, burrata and coriander pesto, chicken kebab and crispy raviolis. To conclude your day in the city, a trip to the Nolinski Spa by La Colline is a must.

Nolinski Paris
16, avenue de l'Opéra
75001 Paris

+33 (0)1 42 86 10 10

www.nolinskiparis.com/?lang=en

Rooms: from 402 EUR

content.title: Popolare, a charming pizzeria by Big Mamma

introduction.small: The Big Mamma group took over the rue Réaumur with products imported directly from Italy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Popolare, a charming pizzeria by Big Mamma

paragraphs.text:
At just 30, chef Salvatore Moscato opens the doors of his pizzeria with its allure of a chic canteen, imagined by the British architect, Macaulay Sinclair. Scents of tomatoes and various artisanal cheeses waft your way escaping from the immense open kitchen, decorated with electric blue tiles. On the menu, there is the “Reine des Neiges” (“Snow Queen”), featuring a San Marzano tomato sauce base, cooked mushrooms, cooked ham with herbs, mozzarella fior di latte, taggiasca olives, and green oil infused with mint and parsley. If you still have space, add some Italian style street-food dishes such as nocchiona (fennel salami), fried dishes to share or artichokes alla giudia.

A little thirsty? No problem. Le Popolare has the largest bar in Paris with no fewer than 500 types of alcohol and cocktails. And since partying is a speciality of the Big Mamma collective, you can also enjoy live concerts and parties until 2 a.m. every Thursday and Saturday night.

content.title: Spoon 2, for the love of world cuisines

introduction.small: If you enter Alain Ducasse's Spoon 2, know that you are embarking on a roller coaster of world gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spoon 2, for the love of world cuisines

paragraphs.text:
From Mexico to Vietnam via Lebanon, the world-famous chef Alain Ducasse, holder of three Michelin stars for three different restaurants, has just opened a fusion cuisine concept offering flavours from all over the world, here in the heart of the 2nd arrondissement of Paris. Here, small wooden tables lit by ceiling-mounted lights come together in a cosy, almost secretive atmosphere, punctuated by a few orange and cobalt-blue seats. Some customers prefer to lean at the restaurant counter, taking their time to enjoy a carefully chosen glass of wine.

Mumbai prawns, taameyya from Cairo, cuttlefish from Sanaa, dürüm from Istanbul, meagre from Damas…these are just some of the ingredients in the dishes from the four corners of the globe that Alain Ducasse has developed. Depart from Constantinople with your starter, travel through Rajasthan for your main course and then set off for Khor al Adaid, in the south-eastern peninsula of Qatar, by ordering a pear with walnuts, lemon and incense. Here more than ever, the cuisine will transport you in every sense.

Spoon 2
Palais Brongniart
25 place de la Bourse
75002 Paris

+33 (0)1 83 92 20 30

https://www.spoon-restaurant.com/en/

Menu: from 39 EUR

content.title: The Cod House, the Rising Sun on a plate

introduction.small: After the success of its Yoko canteen in the Bourse District, the BlackCode Group invites you to an address with deliciously Asian overtones: welcome to The Cod House.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Cod House, the Rising Sun on a plate

paragraphs.text:
In the famous Parisian district of Saint-Germain-des-Prés, a stone's throw from the Jardin du Luxembourg and the Église Saint-Sulpice, The Cod House attracts crowds of gourmets who come to taste the fresh, original Franco-Japanese-inspired dishes of the establishment. Like in a Japanese izakaya (which is to Japan what a bistro or wine bar is to France, a pub to England or a tapas bar to Spain), you lean over the counter to enjoy a cocktail conjured up the bartender to suit your taste and mood, using a selection of yuzu, matcha or sake from Japan's finest producers.

In a light-filled, urban loft-like space, take the time to relax on the cushions of the long and comfortable bench seats, then order some plates of tasty tapas. On the menu, Caesar salad revisited with wasabi, Tokyo patatas bravas, crispy chicken baos with a tonkatsu sauce, green tea crème brûlée.... Tempted?

The Cod House
1 rue de Condé
75006 Paris

+33 (0)1 42 49 35 59

www.thecodhouse.fr

Menu: tapas from 5 EUR

content.title: The solar cooking of Limon

introduction.small: Hotel Marignan's restaurant continues to be the talk of the town. It is high time to head over to the famous Limon brasserie.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The solar cooking of Limon

paragraphs.text:
Replacing Nubé, Limon seduces gourmets with its generous portions, freshly prepared by the head chef. On the menu, sun-drenched cuisine prepared with the best local produce, with subtle Mediterranean accents.
Just a few steps from the Champs-Élysées, this entirely new hybrid space, between a bar and a restaurant, opens onto a large street-front terrace, creating a more relaxed yet equally charming gourmet universe than its predecessor. Fresh, inspired and generously served cuisine is the establishment's credo, with citrus fruits the star of the show. The menu devised by chef Mohamed Seddiki, who grew up in France and Algeria, focuses on dishes each more colourful than the one before. Marignan chicken nems, cod loin with garlic spinach, grilled cuttlefish and mildly spiced aubergine caviar and beef tataki with miso and lemongrass are some of the most exquisite options on the menu. Welcome to Limon!

Limon
14, rue de Marignan
75008 Paris

+33 (0)1 71 93 96 57

https://www.restaurant-limon.fr/en/

Menu: around 47 EUR

content.title: Yaya restaurants: imminent departure for Greece

introduction.small: Head to the sun in Saint-Ouen, the Halle Secrétan or La Défense, to taste delicious Greek specialties revisited. A guaranteed change of scenery!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yaya restaurants: imminent departure for Greece

paragraphs.text:
A Mediterranean getaway awaits you at the Yaya restaurant, in the heart of the docks of Saint-Ouen, less than two kilometres outside of the Paris city limits. Thanks to the Chantzios brothers, you will feel like you are in Neochori-Ithomi, the village of their yaya (grandmother in Greek) in the Peloponnese region. The decor is made up of long sea ropes hanging from the bar and braided lanterns overhanging the banquettes, in a gigantic room bathed in light.

This ultramodern Greek tavern offers a multitude of dishes based on local products. As a starter, share traditional meze on homemade bread with olive oil. Then, opt for pretty garnished plates, such as osso buco in pine honey with seasonal tabbouleh, or grilled cuttlefish accompanied by a lemon-flavoured chickpea mash with piment d'Espelette. For dessert, go for the Yaya orange cake or the chocolate cake with olive oil, black salt and orange zest.

Building on the success of this first restaurant, the Chantzios brothers have recreated the “Yaya” experience in the Halle Secrétan, in heart of the 19th arrondissement, and on the forecourt of La Défense, in Puteaux. The restaurants reflect the soft mood of the peninsula, using delicate natural light as well as shades of white and blue. None of them will disappoint. Just imagine the sound of the waves to perfect the illusion of a trip to the land of Olympus...

Yaya Saint-Ouen

content.title: Hôtel Panache, the elegance of geometry

introduction.small: An attractive boutique hotel in the 9th arrondissement, the Hotel Panache is both discreet and trendy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel Panache, the elegance of geometry

paragraphs.text:
In the Grands Boulevards neighbourhood where the buzz of the capital continues night and day, enter this hotel with interior design by Dorothée Meilichzon, who was inspired by the New York City's Flatiron Building. Geometric lines and triangular patterns punctuate the different spaces with modernity. The seven-storey building features contemporary rooms with large, light-coloured curtain panels, circular hanging lamps, sleek tapestries and crisp linens. The charming hotel perfumes the crossroads of Faubourg-Montmartre and Geoffrey-Marie streets with the delicious aromas of its restaurant. On the menu, masterfully designed by chef Hugo Lafaurie, expect dishes prepared with delicate seasonal products, constantly updated to offer its customers a range of flavours provided by artisans from all over France. This elegant blend is sure to make your stay memorable. All this, and you are just a few moments from the Musée Grévin, too.

Hôtel Panache
1, rue Geoffroy-Marie
75009 Paris

+33 (0)1 47 70 85 87

https://hotelpanache.com/en/

Rooms: from 130 EUR

content.title: In the heart of stony The Hoxton, Paris

introduction.small: In an elegant residence of the 2nd arrondissement, The Hoxton has become the Eldorado for passing visitors and lifelong Parisians.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the heart of stony The Hoxton, Paris

paragraphs.text:
With its exquisitely crafted, 18th-century stone façade, The Hoxton, Paris makes its presence felt on rue du Sentier. Not so long ago, this magnificent building, which was originally constructed for Étienne Rivié, advisor to Louis XV, was still a textile factory. Nowadays, it is one of the capital's trendiest hotels, where tourists and locals gather in a contemporary and relaxed atmosphere.

Put down your suitcases in one of the stylishly decorated rooms with woodwork and cornices, punctuated with pieces of furniture signed by the greatest designers. Stroll around the perfectly preserved, centuries-old cobblestones in the courtyard, order a colourful cocktail at the lobby bar, enjoy a steak in the atmosphere of a French-style brasserie, or take time for a yoga class between two conferences. A must!

The Hoxton
30-32, rue du Sentier
75002 Paris

Tel : +33 (0)1 85 65 75 00

https://thehoxton.com/france/paris/hotels

Rooms: from 160 EUR

content.title: Astier, enhanced terroir

introduction.small: Created six decades ago, Astier is one of the restaurants that sets the standard in Parisian bistro cuisine. Discover a unique choice of meats grilled with charcoal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Astier, enhanced terroir

paragraphs.text:
Ready to enjoy French cuisine in all its finery? See you at Astier then, where meats are cooked by the book since 1956, and where you can enjoy generous servings of seasoned dishes. Now run by chefs Cyril Boulet and Mathieu Le Tirrand, the kitchen in the heart of the 11th arrondissement perpetuates the original values ​​of Mr. and Mrs. Astier, committed to offering a delicious menu at reasonable prices.

Discover Parisian hospitality between the panelled walls of a traditional, even retro, restaurant. Sit down at one of the modest wooden tables of the bistro, while waiters serve you slices of chicken liver terrine, old-style blanquette de veal served with pilau rice, a puff pastry pie with confit vegetables and endive salad with nuts or a vegan assortment of roasted seasonal vegetables. Finish with a classic Astier rum baba or an apple and pear crumble. A real delight!

Restaurant Astier
44 rue Jean-Pierre Timbaud
75011 Paris

+33 (0)1 43 57 16 35

www.restaurant-astier.com/en/

Menu: around 44 - 46 EUR

content.title: Balagan or Israeli-style treats

introduction.small: A gourmet favourite, the Balagan restaurant is a star of Oriental gastronomy, Israeli cuisine in particular.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Balagan or Israeli-style treats

paragraphs.text:
Iconic figures of Israeli cuisine, Assaf Granit and Uri Navon have opened a spot on the ground floor of the Renaissance Paris Vendôme. Parisian gastronomes rush to book their tables at Balagan, a Hebrew name which means “joyous bazaar”, in reference to the atmosphere of the Ma'hané Yehuda market in Jerusalem, and the its contagious good mood..

You might enjoy a starter of a salad of chickpeas and figs for example, or a Balagan polenta with asparagus, mushrooms, Parmesan and truffle-flavoured olive oil. Continue with shredded “jospered” octopus, white onions, cherry tomatoes, marrow bone pita, zaatar and sumac; and if you feel like it, finish with a Jerusalem cheesecake or a tasty Crack Pie. These flavours, textures and ingredients are skilfully combined to create a mood-boosting, joyful experience, all surrounded by decor by designer Dorothée Meilichzon!

Balagan
9 rue d'Alger
75001 Paris

+33 (0)1 40 20 72 14

www.balagan-paris.com/en

Menu: from 48 EUR

content.title: The daily grind and… BOB

introduction.small: Only a few steps away from the Montparnasse station, the BOB Hotel & Coworking space is bound to become your new HQ.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The daily grind and… BOB

paragraphs.text:
You will not only book a room in the heart of Paris' 14th arrondissement, but also, if you choose, set up camp and run those grey cells in your choice of the three working areas offered by the establishment. Between the patio and its high green plants, dark wooden bookcases and colourful geometrical shapes, you will find something to your taste at BOB Hotel & Coworking.
Do you have a meeting at 9 am? It's not a problem, you just have to book the meeting room. A large removable table, cosy chairs and soft sofas make it a very comfortable place to think and be creative! Enjoy various services, like breakfast from 7 am to 11 am, as well as a bar and a hammam. More than just a workplace, BOB is a meeting spot. You can take your pick of three rooms painted in modern colours, and smartphones for customer use are also available in self-service for the duration of your stay!

BOB Hotel & Coworking
30 rue Pernety
75014 Paris

+33 (0)1 40 43 02 33

https://bobhotelparis.com/en/

Rooms: from 115 EUR

content.title: At L'Escargot 1903, bistronomy is in the spotlight

introduction.small: Sometimes, one has to go beyond the gates of Paris to discover chic bistros that are more Parisian than the Parisians.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At L'Escargot 1903, bistronomy is in the spotlight

paragraphs.text:
A short walk from La Défense, the former tavern of the city of Puteaux, L'Escargot 1903, was completely revamped a few years ago. Behind this radical makeover is Yannick Tranchant, who started out as a pastry chef and is self-taught. Not that this prevented him from doing a masterful turn at the Sheraton Roissy and La Grande Cascade. Smiling and full of enthusiasm, the chef offers a flavourful cuisine with a light refined touch. The market-based menu changes according to the seasons. You will be able to taste fish like cod served with season vegetables, pomelos and shells, or meats like beef cooked with caramelised onions, polenta fries and gravy. On sunny days, relish a dessert on the small terrace adjoining the restaurant or enjoy a cocktail, sunglasses on your nose, like a true Parisian.

L'Escargot 1903
94 rue Sadi Carnot
92800 Puteaux

+33 (0)1 47 75 03 66

https://www.lescargot1903.com

Menu: from 35 EUR

content.title: A journey in Champagne country: from Paris to Reims and Épernay

introduction.small: Unveil the secrets of the most famous champagne cellars on this superb day-trip from Paris to the cradle of French sparkling wines

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A journey in Champagne country: from Paris to Reims and Épernay

paragraphs.text:
A trip to Paris offers an extraordinary insight into France's refined cuisine, celebrated wine-making traditions, and magnificent architecture. The "City of Light" is a unique window onto the world-famous French lifestyle, best symbolised by champagne.

Begin your discovery of the eponymous French region by enjoying an exclusive tasting of exceptional sparkling wines in a refined setting overlooking the Eiffel Tower in Paris. Next, take a short train ride of around 45 minutes to Champagne itself, the birthplace of French "bubbly".

Explore Reims or Épernay, where your bespoke tour gives you entry to the most renowned Champagne houses. There, lose yourself in the labyrinth of underground cellars, where millions of bottles of Champagne age peacefully. Finish the day in style with a private tour of some Grandes Maisons on the splendid Avenue de Champagne in Épernay, to find out why Champagne is the quintessential symbol of prestige. Whether or not you are a wine lover, a visit to these UNESCO World Heritage vineyards, just 140 km from Paris, should not be missed.

Wine Paths

+33 (0)5 57 78 43 47

Click here to book your exclusive tours at the greatest Champagne houses

content.title: YOTELAIR, comfort and design to relax in between flights

introduction.small: Do you have a connecting flight at Terminal 2 at Paris-Charles-de-Gaulle airport? YOTELAIR welcomes you for a night or even just a few hours, not far from your check-in!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: YOTELAIR, comfort and design to relax in between flights

paragraphs.text:
There is no visa required for YOTELAIR, as it is nestled in the heart of the new lounge area at Paris-Charles de Gaulle airport, Instant Paris. Waiting for hours in painful positions is a thing of the past! Designed especially for travellers awaiting connecting flights, this hotel concept offers capsule-styled rooms, as in a first-class cabin. In a limited space (9 to 10 sqm) but offering every possible convenience - deluxe mattress, multimedia panel with flat screen TV and international channels, free wi-fi and a bathroom with rain shower – you can spend an hour or two with complete peace of mind.
Do you need to plan a meeting? To relax and play a board game? Then head to the hotel lounge where you'll find vending machines for food and drinks, games, a large coworking table and a semi-private area equipped with international sockets.
Please note that only long-distance travellers connecting at Terminal 2E (gates K, L and M) can access the hotel space, provided they have no checked-in luggage to pick up.

YOTELAIR Paris-Charles-de-Gaulle
Paris-Charles-de-Gaulle airport
Terminal 2E

95746 Roissy-Charles-De-Gaulle Cedex

https://www.yotel.com/en/hotels/yotelair-paris-charles-de-gaulle

content.title: FAST FASHIONABLE FOOD

introduction.small: Co-owners of Roca neo-brasserie and Roco pizzeria, Alexandre Giesbert and Julien Ross have turned to chic, cheap kebab.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: FAST FASHIONABLE FOOD

paragraphs.text:
Everything is homemade here, from the fries and thick ketchup to the pickles and bread, simultaneously soft and crisp. It's the fragrant smell of bread that invites us to come into this small bistro. Its polished concrete floor, black formica tables, Breuer chairs and bare bulbs hanging from the ceiling signal that this place is about the essentials. For here it is a sandwich of Turkish origin that is king. There are several kinds thanks to Chloé Charles, formerly of the restaurant Septime. Among the choices are lamb enhanced with a pinch of curry, falafel (a chickpea dumpling) or orange caramelised pig slow-roasted on a spit. All served in a Boy Scout-style bowl.

Rococo
4, rue du Faubourg Saint-Martin
75010 Paris
No bookings

www.rococokebab.fr

content.title: Sofitel Paris Le Faubourg, the most prestigious boutiques on your doorstep

introduction.small: With its signature design by Didier Gomez, this stylish 5-star hotel has entered the big league.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Paris Le Faubourg, the most prestigious boutiques on your doorstep

paragraphs.text:
Located in an 18th-century former private mansion, the Sofitel Paris Le Faubourg is a flagship of the AccorHotels group in Paris, with every possible luxurious aspect highlighted to secure an upper customer base.

Fashion houses, ministries and business offices are plentiful in this very chic part of the 8th arrondissement, the hotel being also very close to the Élysée Palace, which guarantees the presence of various hosts and event parties.

Thanks to the designer Didier Gomez, the elegance and cultural DNA of the Faubourg Saint-Honoré are everywhere to be found once you enter the double doors, happily mixing 18th century furniture and contemporary paintings, sculptures and photography. You will find the same very successful mix in the hotel's 148 very “boudoir revisited” rooms and suites, as well as at the Blossom restaurant, where chef Alexandre Auger will delight you with his sophisticated vegetarian cuisine. Enjoy Hermès amenities before sliding into the very best MyBed bedding for some haute couture sleep.

Hôtel Sofitel Paris Le Faubourg
15, rue Boissy d'Anglas
75008 Paris

+33 (0)1 44 94 14 14

https://www.sofitel-paris-lefaubourg.com/en/

Rooms: from 351 EUR

content.title: La Cantine du Troquet Daguerre - South-western cuisine

introduction.small: Chef Christian Etchebest's Bearnese soul delights taste buds in his third restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Cantine du Troquet Daguerre - South-western cuisine

paragraphs.text:
With its tables and wooden chairs, metro-tiled bar, rugby shirts, photos of the French rugby team, red and black tiled floor, and slate wall, the decor is like the food served here: authentic. The signature dishes on which the reputations of Chef Etchebest's restaurants in Paris's Pernety and Dupleix neighbourhoods are all here and are sure to win over diners in the new place, too. Razor clams à la plancha, black pudding parmentier and traditional jugged hare are familiar fare, masterfully prepared by Christian Etchebest and Nicolas Gras, the pastry chef with three Michelin stars to his name. The two have collaborated to devise a delicious menu from the starters to the desserts. Besides the classics, there are also the grilled pigs ears with pesto and piment d'Espelette. You will not be disappointed.

La Cantine du Troquet Daguerre
89 rue Daguerre
75014 Paris

+33 (0)1 43 20 20 09

www.lacantinedutroquet.com/la-cantine-daguerre.html

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: Hôtel Paradis, closer to the stars

introduction.small:
With its picture-book image and trendy decor, this small hotel is a perfect stopover for Paris-lovers.
.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel Paradis, closer to the stars

paragraphs.text:
In a few short years, this small hotel in the 10th arrondissement, halfway between the Gare du Nord and the Grands Boulevards, has become a charming boutique address in a thriving neighbourhood. When the Breton couple, Julie and Adrien Gloaguen, acquired their 38-room hotel, they wanted to make it perfect. And they succeeded, to say the very least. Obviously, they were helped hugely by the incredible view of zinc roofs from many of the rooms. To perfect the result, they also hired the much-lauded designer Dorothy Meilichzon, who designed the Bachaumont and Grand Pigalle, and restaurants like Mathis and Beef Club. Her design oscillates between romanticism and humour, evident in the birds of paradise on the walls and a huge Vuitton trunk for a reception desk. The rooms are sleekly styled and enhanced by lights to which only she has the secret, giving the rooms a warm, cosy atmosphere.

Hôtel Paradis
41, rue des Petites-Écuries
75010 Paris

+33 (0)1 45 23 08 22

https://hotelparadisparis.com/en/

Rooms: from 126 EUR

content.title: Grand Central - wide open spaces

introduction.small: In the north-east of the capital, Centquatre Paris is an ideal base for alternative art lovers and fans of good food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand Central - wide open spaces

paragraphs.text:
There are plenty of tables at Centquatre Paris, located between the Stalingrad and La Villette neighbourhoods in the 19th arrondissement, but no two are the same. The Caché café is hidden in the depths of this cultural centre like no other, created on the site of the former municipal funeral services, while Grand Central has replaced the Grandes Tables in the Curial nave. The decor, by designer Sébastien Wierinck, plays on the vastness of the venue: an oversized marble bar, exposed pipes and endless tables. The menu features all the classics. Young chef Mathieu Cormier has mastered the spelt rillettes with autumn vegetable casserole, chicken suprême, homemade fish and chips, and cut Charolais beef tartare... This large space also lends itself perfectly to the restaurant's huge Sunday brunches, which more than live up to their promise of being child-friendly.

Grand Central
5 rue Curial
75019 Paris

+33 (0)9 51 22 76 44

https://www.grandcentral-104.paris/

Menu: around 31 EUR

content.title: Hôtel Henriette - bohemian Left Bank

introduction.small: After Marcel and Edgar, now it's Henrietta's turn to enrich the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel Henriette - bohemian Left Bank

paragraphs.text:
Located on a small street near historic rue Mouffetard, in the oldest district in the capital after île de la Cité, Henriette breaks with the conventions of the Parisian hotel industry and especially that of the Left Bank. Thirty-two single rooms transport us to a world more akin to a Berlin loft than a Napoleonic house. Wood and solid colours bring together peacock blue, yellow and white. There are vintage fabrics from the flea market, always picked out with excellent taste, and 50s-inspired Danish furniture.

However, the decor designed by journalist Vanessa Scoffier, drawing on memories from her childhood, is not the only asset of this doll's house. It also has a 21st century, friendly concierge to give you a helping hand, and a small conservatory where delicious homemade breakfasts are served. A secret address for those in the know.

Hôtel Henriette Rive Gauche
9, rue des Gobelins
75013 Paris

+33 (0)1 47 07 26 90

https://hotelhenriette.com/en/

Rooms: from 79 EUR

content.title: La Belle Époque, explore 20th-century Paris

introduction.small: La Belle Époque is a legendary setting for classics revisited with refinement in the style of the French brasseries of old.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Belle Époque, explore 20th-century Paris

paragraphs.text:
In an Art Nouveau setting, La Belle Époque, once a legendary cabaret in the must-see Opera district, plunges you back into the most memorable literature of the interwar years in Paris.

This, the 1920s decor, and the friendly and attentive staff (with Chef Matthieu Poirier at the helm) will make you appreciate the classic dishes of the French brasseries of old. The majestic mirrors, wide, comfortable seating, coloured concrete flooring and generous space of this typical old-style cabaret set off the beautifully simple cuisine, for example: ceviche of fish of the day, 100-day farmhouse chicken reared on Thierry Dumas' farm in Gers and pavlova with seasonal fruit.

La Belle Époque is a favourite among fashion and film folk too.

La Belle Epoque
36 rue des Petits-Champs
75002 Paris

+33 (0)1 49 27 97 17

https://www.labelleepoqueparis.fr/en/

Menu: around 48 EUR

content.title: Le Bel Ami: for fans of Saint-Germain-des-Prés

introduction.small: Staying in fun, colourful Saint-Germain-des-Prés is like staying with friends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bel Ami: for fans of Saint-Germain-des-Prés

paragraphs.text:
This hotel is tucked inside a 19th-century building which housed the old printing press that published the first copy of Guy de Maupassant's novel Bel-Ami, hence the name. Contemporary in style and decorated with bright colours that awaken you with a smile, the hotel makes you feel at home. At breakfast or for tea and pastry, Maupassant relieves you of any feelings of guilt with this sentence, which you can read in the Bel Ami Café: 'Of all the passions, the only really respectable one, it seems to me, is gluttony.' It is difficult not to succumb to Chef Simon Souzineau's hearty organic brunch at weekends or to indulge oneself at Spa by Maison Flamel. Ideally located between Rue Bonaparte and Boulevard Saint-Germain, Le Bel Ami is the right place for shopaholics, as well as those drawn to Saint-Germain-des-Prés' particular festive, cultural and trendy soul.

Le Bel Ami
7-11, rue Saint-Benoît
75006 Paris

+33 (0)1 42 61 53 53

https://www.hotelbelami-paris.com/

Rooms: from 242 EUR

content.title: Le Coq Rico: chicken supreme

introduction.small: An atypical address with chic and elegant décor, which serves the best of the barnyard.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Coq Rico: chicken supreme

paragraphs.text:
Located in the heart of Montmartre, this unique yet well-known establishment has quickly made a name for itself among connoisseurs. Three-starred chef Antoine Westermann presents a restaurant which focuses on the humble chicken. Armed with his unique imagination and countless recipes each as original as the other, Westermann wonderfully prepares chicken in all its forms.

Go for the roasted chicken – whole or in pieces – there are at least three different kinds (Challans, Bresse, Bourgueil, etc). It is served with its own jus, home fries, macaroni gratin, or green salad in the warmer season. You can also rediscover chicken soup, chicken broth, chicken vol-au-vent, chicken terrine, chicken livers, and many other poultry variations.

And because there can be no chicken without eggs (or is it the other way around?), there are many egg dishes to choose from as well: sunny side up, boiled, fried, or Russian style, served with delicious mayonnaise and mixed crunchy vegetables.

Le Coq Rico
98 rue Lepic
75018 Paris

+33 (0)1 42 59 82 89

https://lecoqrico.com

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: Le Cinq Codet: hidden from view

introduction.small: École Militaire, Champs de Mars, and Invalides are all equidistant from this combination of charm and elegance, which will seduce even the most demanding guests.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Cinq Codet: hidden from view

paragraphs.text:
Seemingly far from the bustle of the city, this five-star hotel is strictly for insiders. Opened in 2015 in the very chic, very quiet 7th arrondissement, its 1930s facade contrasts with those of neighbouring Haussmannian buildings. Architect Jean-Philippe Nuel designed it as a pied-à-terre in a contemporary style with subtle industrial and artistic touches. Like apartments that belong to collectors, the 67 rooms and suites easily lend themselves to guests who want to make them their own. Imagine putting your luggage down in an artist's studio among 400 artworks that truly make you feel like you are in someone's home. Returning from a visit to the Rodin or the Orsay museum, enjoy a break in front of the fireplace, or survey your purchases from the neighbourhood shops on Rue Clerc and Rue St. Dominic away from prying eyes, comfortably installed on a wide, comfortable, circular bench under a parasol on the plant-filled patio. At the end of a lovely day, recline on a lounger in front of the bamboo plants before slipping into the outdoor Jacuzzi. This is pure relaxation.

Le Cinq Codet
5, Rue Louis Codet
75007 Paris

+33 (0)1 53 85 15 60

https://lecinqcodet.com/en/

Rooms: from 280 EUR

content.title: La Régalade Saint-Honoré, spearheading the bistronomic movement

introduction.small: Chef Bruno Doucet's restaurant highlights modern French bistronomic cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Régalade Saint-Honoré, spearheading the bistronomic movement

paragraphs.text:
La Régalade Saint-Honoré impresses with its friendly hospitality, impeccable service, and old-world atmosphere. It has a chic, understated feel and minimalist, pared back, contemporary decor, with pale-coloured walls and red seating creating a warm, authentic terroir restaurant.

On the menu, the chef Bruno Doucet, who honed his skills in the kitchens of French gastronomic greats like Charles Barrier, Jean-Pierre Vigato and Pierre Gagnaire, serves up a creamy cuttlefish ink risotto with stir-fried king prawns and ham, garlic and parsley. Follow that with a steak of meagre fish cooked on the skin with fennel, gravy in basil and an herb salad. Alternatively, the slow-cooked veal hock confit in gravy and served with glazed seasonal vegetables in sage butter wins a vote of confidence. To complete this culinary experience, order the "Venezuela" chocolate pudding cake and homemade coffee ice cream, the star dessert at La Régalade. Very fresh cuisine that will undoubtedly surprise you! Be sure to book ahead.

La Régalade Saint-Honoré
106 rue Saint-Honoré
75001 Paris

+33 (0)1 42 21 92 40

https://www.laregalade.paris

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: La Dame de Pic: the queen of our hearts

introduction.small: This Parisian restaurant is a gastronomic ace, and its kitchen, open to the street, needs no cards hidden up its sleeve.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Dame de Pic: the queen of our hearts

paragraphs.text:
In the female celebrity chef category, Anne-Sophie Pic with her 8 Michelin stars is the grande dame of the Parisian restaurant scene and the most decorated female chef in the world.

This master restaurateur has set out to create a feminine establishment, in shades of pale pink and white, and an intimate, relaxed atmosphere. Come here, and you will always be playing your cards right. On the menu, you will love the flame-grilled Vendée mackerel accompanied by roast artichoke with green chartreuse and warm vinaigrette with smoked pike caviar; or the squab pigeon sourced from the Anezo de Mesquer family, marinated with red vine leaf and blackcurrant leaf.

We shall not taint the surprise of the full menu. This restaurant has many strengths, including long tables d'hôte and a 49-euro lunch menu. Admit that you cannot "pass" this one!

La Dame de Pic
20 rue du Louvre
75001 Paris

+33 (0)1 42 60 40 40

https://www.anne-sophie-pic.com/paris/?lang=en

content.title: Mama Shelter Paris East, an all-inclusive experience

introduction.small: Bring your tribe to this trendy and fashionable haven for hipsters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mama Shelter Paris East, an all-inclusive experience

paragraphs.text:
The hotel/restaurant/bar multi-concept of Mama Shelter Paris East, by Philippe Starck and the Trigano family, appeals to the child within you. As in other cities where the chain is located, the hotel caters to urban souls who need to relax and go back to 'Mama'.

At Mama Shelter Paris East, imagination is the key word and relaxation is the only thing on your schedule. Do not be surprised to find a Darth Vader mask in the room, chalk scribbling on the walls, boisterous games on a huge foosball table, restaurant meals where your fellow diners quickly become friends, and a memorable pizzeria.

Just like mum, 'Mama' takes care of everything, from toothbrushes you might have forgotten to pack to trendy sleep masks, as well as a selection of other products at the hotel shop worthy of the best concept stores. If you have trouble sleeping, go to the rooftop and let yourself be lulled by the hammock. Close your eyes... Mama is watching over you.

Mama Shelter Paris East

75020 Paris

https://mamashelter.com/paris-east

content.title: Manko Paris: Peru to Paris

introduction.small: In the heart of the Golden Triangle, marked out by avenues Montaigne, Champs-Élysées and George-V, Manko Paris opens its doors in the former Drouot auction house.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Manko Paris: Peru to Paris

paragraphs.text:
Part of the Moma Group, Manko is named after the legendary Incan, Manco Capac, son of the Sun God, founder of the Incan people, and an important symbol for the Peruvian community.

In this unique, majestic setting, top chef Gaston Acurio offers a sumptuous culinary voyage, reinventing the subtleties of the traditional dishes of Andean culture. This invitation to travel extends to the decor, with its gilding and noble materials, a perfect balance between a bohemian Peruvian feel and Parisian chic.

On the menu, opt for the Clasico - wild fish ceviche (fish changing according to daily deliveries), sweet potato, corn and tiger's milk. Or try the mouth-watering grilled octopus with potato cream, anticuchera sauce (spicy beef sauce), black olives and garlic chips. A cocktail bar and cabaret will complete your evening journey into Incan lands, every Friday and Saturday evening from midnight.

Manko Paris

content.title: Les Bains Paris: nightclub-turned-hotel

introduction.small: Now you are allowed to fall into the arms of Morpheus in a place where many a memorable night was spent dancing till dawn.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Bains Paris: nightclub-turned-hotel

paragraphs.text:
An institution on the Parisian nightclub scene in the 1980s, Les Bains turned 80 in March 2015. This hotel was once the legendary Parisian club where Warhol and De Niro rocked the world, where Prince put on impromptu concerts, and happy revellers partied with Jack Nicholson, always surrounded by the most beautiful girls in the world.

Owner Jean-Pierre Marois has revived the spirit of Les Bains with this hotel, complete with restaurant, patios, suites, concert hall, bar, boudoir lounge, and club, to say nothing of the impressive spa. In this new metamorphosis, sleep, thankfully, is not a sacrilege. Forty rooms and suites (ranging from 23 to 80 sqm, some with lovely terraces), as well as the penthouse are decorated with unique works in much the same way as artists' homes are. Architect Vincent Bastie and Tristan Auer, whom Mick Jagger commissioned to decorate his homes around the world, designed the decor. A true Parisian experience.

content.title: Le Pavillon de la Reine, the charm of yesteryear Paris.

introduction.small: For one or two nights, pretend you are a resident of Place des Vosges, one of the oldest squares in Paris, just as Victor Hugo, Georges Simenon, and Colette once were.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Pavillon de la Reine, the charm of yesteryear Paris.

paragraphs.text:
Discover a portrait in an art gallery under the arches, admire a beautiful object in an antique shop, linger at a table for lunch, read on the lawn in front of the fountain... It is always exhilarating to wander around Place des Vosges, identifiable by its red brick facades and its blue slate roofs. This small architectural gem was built for King Henry IV. The royal privilege to stay here becomes reality with this house (one of 36 on the square) that has been transformed into a five-star hotel. As soon as you cross the threshold, a feeling of another time and another place steals over you. The ivy on the interior facade gives the impression of a soothing cloak of leaves. You are transported to another time, that of Anne, Queen of Austria and of France, who lived in another part of this square in the 17th century. The historical style is maintained but the comfortable rooms reflect the last word in modernity. The epitome of good taste, the Codage group's aptly named Spa de la Reine (Queen's Spa) offers you very best in body treatments - the royal treatment one might say!

Le Pavillon de la Reine
28, Place des Vosges

www.pavillon-de-la-reine.com/en/

Rooms: from 306 EUR

content.title: Le Gavroche: a true Parisian bistro

introduction.small: Enter the Gavroche, near the Bourse (the old stock market), and discover an Epicurean brotherhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Gavroche: a true Parisian bistro

paragraphs.text:
Nicolas Decatoire's friendly welcome, full of humour and sincerity, makes this a truly classic Parisian bistro. People chat with each other at the counter, glass of Beaujolais in hand and plate of sliced dry sausage before them, until their table is ready.

The starters, written on the chalkboard, are simple and excellent: traditional rillettes, devilled eggs, smoked ham or boar terrine. What follows is a short menu of typically French hearty homemade dishes like fried chicken with tarragon, grilled andouillette, escalope with mushrooms, beef stew, or different cuts of beef accompanied by mashed potatoes, rice, or fries. The desserts are displayed on the table: millefeuille, rum baba and apple pie, which Nicolas cuts for you, the size depending on how much room you have left.

This is an address you will love, and one that you will share with the journalists, bankers, and regulars of Hôtel Drouot, the famous Parisian auction house located nearby, who make this their everyday 'canteen' bistro.

Le Gavroche

+33 (0)1 42 96 89 70

Menu: around 33 EUR

content.title: Outspoken theatre

introduction.small: To appreciate Molière's language, choose the Comédie-Française. If contemporary conceptual theatre is more to your taste, opt for the Théâtre du Rond-Point.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Outspoken theatre

paragraphs.text:
The Comédie-Française, founded in 1680 during the reign of Louis XIV, is the quintessence of Italian theatre, lined with burgundy velvet under flamboyant crystal chandeliers. Also referred to simply as “Le Français”, this institution is a buzzing hive composed of a company and three theatres. The Salle Richelieu, an historic theatre in the Palais Royal, presents a classical repertoire (Molière, Racine, Corneille), the Théâtre du Vieux-Colombier showcases foreign authors (Pirandello to Pasolini), and the Studio-Théâtre, situated in the Carrousel du Louvre, has been staging shorter, more diverse pieces since1996.

The Théâtre du Rond-Point, near the Champs-Élysées, is the work of the great set designer Patrick Dutertre, whom director Jean-Michel Ribes entrusted with the renovation, design, decoration and signage of the stages of the complex in 2001. Alongside the three rooms -Topor, Tardieu and Renault-Barrault - which openly show productions of delicious subversion, satire, and fantasy, an abundantly stocked bookshop, a tearoom, and a restaurant for dinner after the show will transform your visit to the Théâtre du Rond-Point into a truly memorable, emotional experience.

Comédie-Française

content.title: Park Hyatt Paris-Vendôme: meet me at Rue de la Paix

introduction.small: Located between the Opera and Place Vendôme, the Park Hyatt is a discreet luxury hotel ideal for business appointments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Park Hyatt Paris-Vendôme: meet me at Rue de la Paix

paragraphs.text:
In the lobby, neutral shades of white stone vie with mahogany woodwork, and the clean lines of its communal areas are the perfect foil for modern sculptures. Like a modern art museum, this contemporary palace hotel fits in well with the jewellers in the neighbourhood. Popular with Parisians who meet in the vast lounges or on the indoor terrace for a gourmet breakfast, this flagship of the luxury Hyatt chain will charm fans of minimalist purity.

Among the 156 rooms, including 45 luxury suites, those overlooking the Place Vendôme are the most attractive, but all have the highest standard of comfort, with service to match. Luxury is, as they say, in the details. The Park Hyatt reassures its knowledgeable clientele with products by Blaise Mautin, the chic Parisian perfumer, and its spa, which carries the coveted La Mer brand products.

The hotel's Pur' restaurant – with chef Jean-François Rouquette at the helm - is a French gastronomical gem and well worth a booking.

content.title: Paris for well-mannered kids

introduction.small: On the edge of the Bois de Boulogne, the Jardin d'Acclimatation has entertained little Parisians since 1932. On the other side of the capital, Disneyland Paris continually renews its charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Paris for well-mannered kids

paragraphs.text:
The Jardin d'Acclimatation is the reward of choice for children who have dutifully visited the Louis Vuitton Foundation. LVMH has managed the park for 20 years and so they offer both attractions on one ticket.

In this iconic park (which you have to pay to enter), inaugurated by Napoleon III in 1860, children can meet over 400 semi-captive animals in shared enclosures. Once you have said hello to the alpacas, miniature goats and lorikeets, young and old will revel in the forty attractions, which include flying boats, the enchanted river and the rollercoaster.

If you love the magic of fairy tales, head for a world-famous amusement park of a completely different kind. Only 35 minutes from the centre of the capital on the RER line A, you can join Mickey and friends at Europe's number one tourist destination, Disneyland Paris. Opened in 1992 as Euro Disney, it continues to refresh and enrich the myth, with six Disney Hotels, two Disney Nature Resorts, and the Disney Village entertainment centre. There are so many rides and attractions that you have the choice of two different theme parks: Disneyland Park, where Sleeping Beauty's castle, magical displays and fabulous parades await, and Walt Disney Studios Park, which celebrates the breathtaking world of Disney and Pixar productions.

content.title: Molitor, an unusual hotel

introduction.small: A luxury hotel has opened within the walls of the famous outdoor swimming pool of the 16th arrondissement, just a stone's throw away from the Roland-Garros stadium.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Molitor, an unusual hotel

paragraphs.text:
One of the last remaining outdoor swimming pools in Paris, it was closed for 25 years. During all that time, it was used as a beautiful 1930s style playground for squatters and street artists. May of 2014 marked its eagerly awaited rebirth. Swimming pool, restaurant or gym? No one really knew what to expect.
It now offers each of the above as an MGallery by Sofitel, part of the collection of historic boutique hotels by AccorHotels. 117 modern rooms, 7 refined suites and a restaurant, led by chef Nader Hassan, all revolve around the central summer pool.
Located outdoors, the latter invites you to a very relaxing breaststroke swim, the water temperature remaining at 28°C all year long. In the meantime, the winter pool and its blue cabins over three levels are a call to more biting crawl movements. The rooftop, perfect for lazing about, and the 1,600-sqm Spa by Clarins will also get your vote of confidence.

content.title: Shoes: a matter of style

introduction.small: At these three classic addresses, you will walk out with magnificent shoes to show off on Paris's sidewalks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shoes: a matter of style

paragraphs.text:
The red soles of his shoes ignited the fashion scene in 1993. This was the year Christian Louboutin, a former designer at Roger Vivier, had a brilliant idea. Inspired by Andy Warhol and Pop Art, he borrowed his assistant's nail polish and painted the soles of a pair of shoes red.

Another leading light in the world of female fashion, Roger Vivier, also known as the “Fragonard of shoes”, is the man whose accomplishments include reviving wedges, and making Marlene Dietrich look even thinner. His shoes for Catherine Deneuve in the film Belle de Jour by Luis Bunuel (1967) also crossed over to everyday wear. The shoe, at Roger Vivier, is not a fashion accessory but the key to Olympus. Nowadays, creative director Gherardo Felloni perpetuates the myth.

Finally, gentlemen, you will have to learn how to sponge, wax, brush, and caress your shoes at Berluti, which has been making refined shoes for men since 1895. For instance, we suggest you try their legendary Andy loafers, inspired by Andy Warhol: they can be customised with your own patina.

content.title: Sport on the banks of the Seine River

introduction.small: Under the bridges of Paris flows the Seine and on its banks, Parisians go running on the stone quays, dazzled by the rich heritage all around them.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sport on the banks of the Seine River

paragraphs.text:
As car traffic has been gradually cut back, the banks of the Seine are slowly reverting to towpaths where nothing can bring down your good mood. These magnificent corridors of peace and beauty are where you come to stay in shape, with or without a running coach. Run down the Seine's Left Bank from the Port Solferino - under the eponymous bridge - to Port du Gros Caillou, and just level with the Musée Branly, take advantage of its climbing wall for 3-10 year olds and a 100-m running track. There is also a 2-3-km fitness trail equipped with gym apparatus, where from early July to late October, you can take free boxing, rope-skipping, Pilates, skateboarding, and rugby classes by booking online. It goes without saying that the magical setting of this urban landscape, which has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1991 and is so beloved of Parisians, also lends itself beautifully to a romantic stroll.

Les Berges

content.title: The capital's 21st-century chapel of art

introduction.small: The brainchild of LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault, the Louis Vuitton Foundation stands out as a magnificent artistic meeting place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The capital's 21st-century chapel of art

paragraphs.text:
You can discern the 12 glass sails of the Louis Vuitton Foundation from the outskirts of the Bois de Boulogne, their 13,500-sqm surface area inflated by the winds of technological prowess. Frank Gehry, the architect of the foundation, whose mandate is to promote creativity, readily spans art and culture. Gehry's bold vessel, with its endless corridors, is ranked as one of the most iconic buildings of the 21st century. Here, LVMH, the world's leading luxury group, displays its contemporary art collection alongside many themed exhibitions. Do not pass up the opportunity to enjoy a concert or other performance at its 1,000-seat auditorium, or a meal at the Le Frank restaurant where Michelin-starred chef Jean-Louis Nomicos' menu changes from hour to hour. Seated below the vast glass ceiling, look up to see Frank Gehry's splendid fish swimming above you.

content.title: The echo of stars, divas, and composers

introduction.small: From legendary operas under the stars, in the most regal and historical settings, to year round performances at the Philharmonic, Paris adores classical music.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The echo of stars, divas, and composers

paragraphs.text:
Since 2001, the open-air opera festival has played the most beautiful sites in and around Paris, including the Musée des Invalides and Chateau de Vincennes. From mid-June to mid-September, the festival gives hundreds of spectators the opportunity to experience an original staging of a classical work. The event, which promotes young talent and great lyrical works among new audiences celebrates all the greats: Mozart, Verdi, Puccini, Bizet, Offenbach, and Rossini.

The Philharmonie de Paris offers a rich program of concerts and performances throughout the year. This incredible, spaceship-like building designed by the architect Jean Nouvel hosts the Paris Chamber Orchestra, the National Orchestra of the Île-de-France, Les Arts Florissants, and, most importantly, prestigious orchestras, international conductors, and soloists from around the world. Its numerous auditoriums – including the Grande Salle Pierre Boulez with its unique acoustics - showcase contemporary and world music, as well as classical repertoire.

content.title: The Royal Monceau - Raffles Paris: now, this is a palace!

introduction.small: Opened in 1928, and modernised in the 21st century by Philippe Starck, this palace reflects the Parisian lifestyle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Royal Monceau - Raffles Paris: now, this is a palace!

paragraphs.text:
A few minutes' walk from the Champs-Élysées is a palace hotel where Parisians like to meet up, which moves at the pace of the city. Its proximity to Parc Monceau, frequented by joggers and nannies, gives an extra something to its chic Avenue Hoche address. The famous designer Philippe Starck has designed the 149 rooms and suites to be luminous white cocoons with mirrors everywhere. There may be a guitar in one room or novels next to the bar-culture and art cater to your artistic side. An Art Concierge guides you through your Parisian cultural journey, whilst a contemporary art gallery, an art bookshop and a 99-seat cinema are unusual and highly appreciated hotel amenities. And, because we are in Paris, the art is also culinary. At the Long Bar, enjoy a Pierre Hermé pastry before booking a table at one of the hotel's two restaurants. It will not be an easy choice, between Matsuhisa Paris, where Nobu's talented Japanese chef captivates with contemporary Asian flavours, and Il Carpaccio, the only Michelin-starred Italian restaurant in Paris. Do not miss the hotel's added bonus: the luxurious My Blend by Clarins Spa, and the largest hotel swimming pool in the city.

Le Royal Monceau – Raffles Paris

content.title: The new, fashionable museum tour

introduction.small: With attractions such as the Rodin Museum, the Museum of Mankind and the Picasso Museum, Paris abounds with art, history and culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The new, fashionable museum tour

paragraphs.text:
The Rodin Museum opened its doors in 1919. It is housed within the former Hôtel Peyrenc de Moras, more commonly known as the “Hôtel Biron”, which was built back in the 18th century. Located in the rue de Varenne, a stone's throw from the Eiffel Tower and Les Invalides, it features works not only by Auguste Rodin, one of the fathers of modern sculpture, but also by his muse, the artist Camille Claudel, spread over two floors. Outside, the sculpture garden provides an opportunity to discover more works by the master, in an magnificent natural setting.

On the Place du Trocadéro in the grounds of the Palais de Chaillot, the Museum of Mankind takes a fascinating and enlightened look at the human race, its history and its future. Its spectacular, 2,500-sqm Gallery of Mankind, one of the museum's showpieces, showcase some of the world's finest anthropological and paleontological collections.

In the heart of the 3rd arrondissement, the national Picasso Museum displays its collections in the Hôtel Salé, one of the most beautiful and most Baroque private mansions in the Marais neighbourhood. This historical property, completely renovated by the architect Jean-François Bodin, contains no fewer than 500 works by Pablo Picasso, the genius Spanish artist, including paintings, sculptures, engravings, and drawings, as well as works by his friends Matisse, Miró and Braque.

content.title: The eternal Café de Flore

introduction.small: In the district of Saint-Germain-des-Prés, Café de Flore, the Left Bank haunt of artists and intellectuals, continues to amaze.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The eternal Café de Flore

paragraphs.text:
This hangout of the Parisian intelligentsia owes its name to a famous sculpture of the goddess of spring, the aptly named “Flora”, located on the other side of the boulevard. In 1917, Guillaume Apollinaire would visit, taking up position near the stove and spending the day dreaming, writing and meeting his surrealist friends André Breton, Paul Reverdy, Louis Aragon and Paul Éluard. A few years later, the first floor of the brasserie was frequented by the couple Jean-Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir. Alongside them, Albert Camus, Raymond Aron and Maurice Merleau-Ponty came here to write their respective works.

In the sumptuous Art Deco room and on the spacious outdoor patio looking out at boulevard Saint-Germain, showbiz celebrities, locals and tourists come and go, enjoying the unique atmosphere of this legendary neighbourhood establishment.

Come here for the traditional hot chocolate, a house speciality, or enjoy a delicious glass of wine. For lunch, dinner, or a drink, Café de Flore is an institution of Parisian life.

Each year, the establishment also hosts the Prix de Flore, created by writer Frédéric Beigbeder, which recognises young French literary talent.

Le Café de Flore

content.title: Louvre Museum: the largest museum of them all

introduction.small: Emblematic establishment of the French capital, the Louvre Museum houses some 35,000 pieces that cast a wide canvass of world history, from the Ancients to 1848.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Louvre Museum: the largest museum of them all

paragraphs.text:
Set up in the former residence of the French Kings, the Louvre is among the most spectacular and popular museums in the world, welcoming about 10 million visitors per year. Within departments of painting, sculpture, archaeology and graphic arts, you will be able to contemplate masterpieces such as the Mona Lisa, the Venus de Milo and the Raft of the Medusa.

The museum's architecture is typical of the classical period, with an added touch of modernity due to the glass pyramid created in 1989 by ‎Leoh Ming Pei. With more than 400 exhibition rooms, the art sweeps over large geographical areas, from Western Europe to Asia or Greece. From the inside of this huge building, you will also enjoy exceptional vistas over some of Paris' most beautiful sites: the Pont-Neuf bridge and the Île de la Cité, the Orsay Museum… Do not leave the Louvre without strolling through the Tuileries Garden, located in the axis of the museum, where the landscaped scenery also conveys a sense of history.

Musée du Louvre

content.title: Vintage hunting in Paris

introduction.small: From flea markets to antique shops, here are two walking tours for all you art lovers and collectors.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vintage hunting in Paris

paragraphs.text:
In norther n Paris, a short walk from Porte de Clignancourt is the Saint-Ouen flea market. Here, you will find the largest concentration of second-hand dealers in the world, with over 2,500 stalls bursting with antiques, photographs, vintage clothing and souvenirs. Best loved by the bargain hunters looking for gems from every era is Antiques Rodriguez Decoration.

Meanwhile, in the heart of the capital, between Saint-Germain-des-Prés and the Orsay Museum, Le Carré Rive Gauche is an unmissable cluster of 120 antique dealers and art galleries. From primitive arts to 21st-century design, all objects are certified and guaranteed. On the Rue du Bac, stop in and see François Hayem, the leading expert on the 18th century, who deals in untouched furniture and objects from the Enlightenment. Hayem has the best eye in the business.

content.title: Dance in pas de deux

introduction.small: Admire the dancers in the Second Empire splendour of the Palais Garnier or amid the Art Deco decor at Chaillot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dance in pas de deux

paragraphs.text:
In Paris, dance is appreciated throughout the year in two bespoke locations: the Opéra de Paris (which actually encompasses two theatres, the Palais Garnier and the Opéra Bastille), and the Palais de Chaillot.

The Opéra has been enjoying a real breath of fresh air since Aurélie Dupont took over as director of dance and set her sights on reinvigorating classical ballet and making that of the Paris Opera the very best in the world. The former prima ballerina wants to attract choreographers with a unique visual style to make her principal dancers and corps de ballet shine, both here and at its sister institution, the Opéra Bastille.

Each year, the Théâtre National de Chaillot offers a very international programme (Carolyn Carlson, Mathilde Monnier, Trisha Brown...) that leaves ample room for regulars like Noé Soulier, Thomas Lebrun and Kader Attoun, as well as long-running productions, often from the Avignon Festival. With an ambitious programme overseen until recently by the imperial Didier Deschamps (succeeded in 2021 by Rachid Ouramdane), Chaillot is proving to be the domain of choreographers.
